org.apache.drill.exec.store.easy.text.compliant

Class TestCsvWithSchema

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.drill.test.BaseTest
      • org.apache.drill.test.DrillTest
        • org.apache.drill.test.ClusterTest
          • org.apache.drill.exec.store.easy.text.compliant.BaseCsvTest
            • org.apache.drill.exec.store.easy.text.compliant.TestCsvWithSchema

  • public class TestCsvWithSchema
extends BaseCsvTest
    Test the schema mechanism in the context of a simple CSV tables. The focus here is on the schema mechanism, which can be explored with simple tables of just a few rows.

    • Nested Class Summary

      • Nested classes/interfaces inherited from class org.apache.drill.test.DrillTest

      • setup

        public static void setup()
                  throws Exception
        Throws:

      • testBasicSchema

        public void testBasicSchema()
                     throws Exception
        Test the simplest possible case: a table with one file:
        • Column in projection, table, and schema
        • Column in projection and table but not in schema.
        • Column in projection and schema, but not in table.
        • Column in projection, but not in schema or table.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testMissingRequiredCol

        public void testMissingRequiredCol()
                            throws Exception
        Show that the projection framework generates a reasonable default value if told to create a required column that does not exist. In this case, the default default [sic] value for an INT column is 0. There is no "default" value set in the schema, so we use a "default default" instead.)
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testRequiredColDefault

        public void testRequiredColDefault()
                            throws Exception
        Use a user-provided default value for a missing required column.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testDateColDefault

        public void testDateColDefault()
                        throws Exception
        Use a user-provided default value for a missing required column.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testMultiFileSchema

        public void testMultiFileSchema()
                         throws Exception
        Use a schema with explicit projection to get a consistent view of the table schema, even if columns are missing, rows are ragged, and column order changes.

        Force the scans to occur in distinct fragments so the order of the file batches is random.

        Throws:
        Exception

      • testWildcardSortFailure

        public void testWildcardSortFailure()
                             throws Exception
        Show that, without schema, the hard schema change for the "missing" gender column causes an error in the sort operator when presented with one batch in which gender is VARCHAR, another in which it is Nullable INT. This is a consequence of using SELECT * on a distributed scan.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testExplicitSort

        public void testExplicitSort()
                      throws Exception
        Because V3 uses VARCHAR for missing columns, and handles ragged rows, there is no vector corruption, and the sort operator sees a uniform schema, even without a schema.

        This and other tests enable multiple scan fragments, even for small files, then run the test multiple times to generate the result set in different orders (file1 first sometimes, file2 other times.)

        Throws:
        Exception

      • testSchemaExplicitSort

        public void testSchemaExplicitSort()
                            throws Exception
        Adding a schema makes the data types more uniform, and fills in defaults for missing columns. Note that the default is not applied (at least at present) if a column is missing within a file that says it has the column.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testMultiFileSchemaMissingCol

        public void testMultiFileSchemaMissingCol()
                                   throws Exception
        Test the case that a file does not contain a required column (in this case, id in the third file.) There are two choices. 1) we could fail the query, 2) we can muddle through as best we can. The scan framework chooses to muddle through by assuming a default value of 0 for the missing int column.

        Inserts an ORDER BY to force a single batch in a known order. Assumes the other ORDER BY tests pass.

        This test shows that having consistent types is sufficient for the sort operator to work; the DAG will include a project operator that reorders the columns when produced by readers in different orders. (Column ordering is more an abstract concept anyway in a columnar system such as Drill.)

        Throws:
        Exception

      • testWildcardLenientSchema

        public void testWildcardLenientSchema()
                               throws Exception
        Test lenient wildcard projection. The schema contains all columns in the table; the schema ensures a consistent schema regardless of file shape or read order. The sort operator works because it sees the consistent schema, despite great variation in inputs.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testWildcardStrictSchema

        public void testWildcardStrictSchema()
                              throws Exception
        Test wildcard projection with a strict schema: only schema columns are projected.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testMultiFragmentStrictSchema

        public void testMultiFragmentStrictSchema()
                                   throws Exception
        Test a strict schema where it is needed most: in a scan with multiple fragments, each of which sees a different reader schema. The output schema ensures that each scan independently reports the same schema, so that the downstream sort operator gets a single consistent batch schema.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testBool

        public void testBool()
              throws Exception
        Test the many ways to specify True for boolean columns. Anything that is not true is false.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testDecimal

        public void testDecimal()
                 throws Exception
        Basic decimal sanity test showing rounding, using default values, and so on.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testDecimalNoPrecOrScale

        public void testDecimalNoPrecOrScale()
                              throws Exception
        Verify that a decimal type without precision or scale defaults to precision of 38, scale of 0.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testDecimalNoScale

        public void testDecimalNoScale()
                        throws Exception
        Verify that a decimal type with no scale defaults to a scale of 0.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testDecimalDefaultRound

        public void testDecimalDefaultRound()
                             throws Exception
        Verify that the decimal default value is rounded according to the scale specified in the decimal type.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testDecimalOverflow

        public void testDecimalOverflow()
                         throws Exception
        Test decimal overflow during data reads. The overflow occurs after rounding the data value of 99999.9 to 100000.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testDecimalDefaultOverflow

        public void testDecimalDefaultOverflow()
                                throws Exception
        Test proper handling of overflow for a default value. In this case, the overflow occurs after rounding.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testInvalidDecimalSchema

        public void testInvalidDecimalSchema()
                              throws Exception
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testMissingCols

        public void testMissingCols()
                     throws Exception
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testMissingColsReq

        public void testMissingColsReq()
                        throws Exception
        Verify that, if a schema is provided, a column is missing, and there is no default, that the mode is left at required and the column is filled with zeros. Note that this behavior is specific to the text readers: if have no schema, even an missing VARCHAR column will be REQUIRED and set to an empty string (reason: if the column does appear it will be a required VARCHAR, so, to be consistent, missing columns are also required.)
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testMissingColsReqDefault

        public void testMissingColsReqDefault()
                               throws Exception
        Verify the behavior of missing columns, not null mode, with a default value.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testMissingColsNullable

        public void testMissingColsNullable()
                             throws Exception
        Demonstrate that CSV works for a schema with nullable types when columns are missing (there is no comma to introduce an empty field in the data.)
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testBlankCols

        public void testBlankCols()
                   throws Exception
        Demonstrate that CSV uses a comma to introduce a column, even if that column has no data. In this case, CSV assumes the value of the column is a blank string.

        Such a schema cannot be converted to a number or date column, even nullable, because a blank string is neither a valid number nor a valid date.

        Throws:
        Exception

      • testBlankColsWithSchema

        public void testBlankColsWithSchema()
                             throws Exception
        Use the same data set as above tests, but use a schema to do type conversion. Blank columns become 0 for numeric non-nullable, nulls for nullable non-numeric.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testBlankColsWithNullableSchema

        public void testBlankColsWithNullableSchema()
                                     throws Exception
        As above, but with a nullable numeric column. Here, by default, blank values become nulls.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • testBlankColsWithNoDefaultValue

        public void testBlankColsWithNoDefaultValue()
                                     throws Exception
        As above, but with a non-nullable numeric column with a default value.
        Throws:
        Exception
